subject: Re: [junit] Testing certain types of methods
msgSnippet: ... Let me try to clarify, since my innocent remark started this. Some designs are difficult to test with JUnit, especially the way I choose to use it. When I
messageBody:
Soaring Eagle wrote:
> Todd,
>
> I dont see the "bad" connotation in the text of my email. Anyways -
> here is the question repeated.
>
> Do you mean that sometimes it is not commercially desirable to
> improvde design and at such times, JUnit's inability to be flexible is
> a limitation?
>
> Group,
>
> I guess I understand what this thread means, but if anyone wants to
> confirm it, that will be good too.

Let me try to clarify, since my innocent remark started this.

Some designs are difficult to test with JUnit, especially the way I
choose to use it. When I come across such a situation, I generally
choose to believe that JUnit is encouraging me to change my design in a
way that makes it better. There are those who choose to believe that
JUnit is unable to test their design, and that's JUnit's fault.

Or:

Sometimes it's difficult to test a given design with JUnit. Some choose
to believe that's a limitation of JUnit; others believe that's a
limitation of the design being tested. I am one of the latter.
--
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
Diaspar Software Services
http://www.diasparsoftware.com
Author, JUnit Recipes: Practical Methods for Programmer Testing
